All of the DNA starts to replicate itself, giving the cell 2 copies of every strand of DNA
Everything that moves around in the nucleus is regulated by these centrosomes.
The set of protein cyllinders next to  nucleus (centrosome) duplicates itself as the process of mitosis starts
The long strings of DNA are loosely coiled and messy. These are caller chromatins.
Interphase is the period prior to the first stage of mitosis. In this period, DNA is loosely coiled
Mitosis takes place in a series of discrete stages called prophase, metaphase, anaphase and telophase
Mitosis allows one cell with 46 chromosomes to split into 2 cells that are genetically identical
The DNA has 46 chromosomes grouped into 23 pairs, where one of the pair is from your father and one from your mother. These are Diploid cells.

This better than my science textbook! Haha

Hank is 1. A good actor 2. Has the benefit of cuts 3. Has no bored or disruptive audience, meaning he has no major distractions from his energy or focus 4. Is (apparently) using a teleprompter (he is looking slightly above the camera) 5. Has perfectly integrated images and videos to keep interest. 6. Has a snappy soundtrack and sound effects. 7. Is able to use a carefully written script with perfectly polished delivery (because 1, 2, 3, and 4).   These are all advantages your ordinary teacher probably lacks. So please, enough "Hank is better than my actual biology teacher!" Hank is something totally other than your teacher, he is a professional presenter with a team. It's kind of like saying "Tom Holland is more charismatic than my actual high school friends." Well yes. Yes he is. But also. . .movie magic / cinema skills. If your teacher had a professional video team and coaching, they may or may not achieve similar results- it is a totally different genre.   None of this is to suggest anything bad about Hank or crash course. It is an amazing product done with high values, a passion for teaching and a very strong work ethic.

IPMAT  Interphase: copy’s  Prophase: nucleus membrane disappearing Metaphase: copy’s line up in the middle cell Anaphase: copy’s are pulled apart to different sides Telophase: new membrane forms around the chromosome  Cytokinesis: they divide into daughter cells   I hope this simplified every thing and helped you, let me know if 8t did :D

An easy trick to memorize the steps to Mitosis!   PASS(prophase) ME(metaphase) A(anaphase) TACO(telephase)    CHIEF(cytokinesis-it's not an actual step but if it helps you can add it on lol)  I didn't use interphase in this little saying since it doesn't actually count as mitosis. It's like the preparation of the actual following steps!

Think about the way all the different types of cells and the organelles of each of those cells work. The process of how life works and how these 9 million+ species each live, reproduce, eat, etc.... requires SO MUCH thought and detail to be taken into consideration that it would be impossible for it to happen just from a big bang and even evolution. Plant cells have walls, so cytokinesis cannot proceed with a cleavage furrow. Instead, during telophase a cell plate forms across the cell in the location of the old metaphase plate. -http://www.phschool.com/science/biology_place/biocoach/mitosisisg/cytokin.html

No they replicated before in interphase. So there was 23 chromosomes with only one arm. They then replicated so there was a second arm- 48 arms (2 arms per chromosome) in 23 pairs, ready to be pulled apart!
